abstract.p: Curt Leviant letter on Barry Gewen Feb 20 review of Eric A Johnson's book Nazi Terror: The Gestapo, Jews and Ordinary Germans (S)

block.p: In the conclusion to his review of Eric A. Johnson's ''Nazi Terror'' (Feb. 20), Barry Gewen constructs an erroneous -- and absurd -- hypothetical situation (''What if word had begun seeping back that Japanese-American children were being murdered . . .?'') in his attempt to compare German silence during the mid-1940's, when Jews were being rounded up for murder, to American silence regarding the internment of Japanese-Americans.

In the conclusion to his review of Eric A. Johnson's ''Nazi Terror'' (Feb. 20), Barry Gewen constructs an erroneous -- and absurd -- hypothetical situation (''What if word had begun seeping back that Japanese-American children were being murdered . . .?'') in his attempt to compare German silence during the mid-1940's, when Jews were being rounded up for murder, to American silence regarding the internment of Japanese-Americans.

It is important to remember that except for a brief period (the Weimar Republic), Germans had lived under authoritarian rule for many decades. Moreover, church-inspired anti-Semitism had been part of the German experience for centuries. It was the unique combination of ultranationalism (the Jew as foreign body) and anti-Semitism (the Jew as Christ-killer) that doomed the Jews, as it did elsewhere whenever this nefarious combination came about.
For Gewen to create an impossible hypothesis and then presume that the California population would have remained silent defies both logic and the history of democratic tradition.
